misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop Reads Input Automatically (Stale Input / No Prompt in Loop)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once they read the first guess into variable g, the while-loop will somehow get new guesses from the user on each iteration (or that g will change automatically), so the game will continue prompting and reading until the number is correct.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables do not change unless assigned. A loop does not automatically re-run input code unless you place `System.out.print(...)` and `g = x.nextInt()` inside the loop body. As written, the program reads input at most once (before the loop). Then the loop reuses the same value of `g` forever, causing an infinite loop if the first guess is wrong and nonzero.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Typically an infinite loop printing "Too high!" or "Too low!" repeatedly (and incrementing the guess counter) without ever asking for a new guess; program appears to hang/spam output.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Misplaced Counter Increment (Counting Outputs Not Attempts)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes incrementing `c` inside each branch of the logic correctly counts guesses, even if the same guess is being reused, and that the counter should increase whenever the loop checks the guess.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The number of guesses should increment once per user attempt (i.e., once per successful read of a new integer). Here `c` increments every loop iteration, not per input. With the current structure, after one wrong guess, the loop repeats endlessly and `c` grows without bound, even though the user made only one guess.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Incorrect guess count (rapidly increasing); in the infinite-loop case, it never reaches a sensible final count.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Using Sentinel Value 0 to Exit Without Spec (Conflating Input Validity with Game Control)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that checking `if(g!=0)` inside the loop is a reasonable way to control the game (e.g., 0 means stop), or that `g` might become 0 automatically when input is exhausted/invalid.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The problem statement does not define 0 as a quit command. Also, `g` will not become 0 unless the program assigns 0 to it (or it was never read and remains its initial value). Because input is not read in the loop, `g` will never change to 0 after the first read, so this condition does not help termination and can mask logic errors.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Either premature termination when the user enters 0 (even though not specified), or no termination help at all in the common case.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that reading from the Scanner once into a variable (g) before the loop starts is sufficient to capture all future user inputs, or that the variable will automatically refresh itself with new keyboard input every time the loop repeats.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, input methods like Scanner.nextInt() are discrete commands that execute exactly once per call. To obtain a series of inputs, the method must be invoked inside the loop body. Variables do not have a 'live' connection to the input stream; they only store the specific value assigned at the moment of execution.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the if-statement logic used to capture the first guess (lines 11-19) is somehow implicitly 'linked' to the while-loop that follows, or that the program can jump back to previous lines of code to get a new guess.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java execution is strictly sequential unless directed by control flow statements. Once the program enters the while-loop at line 21, it cannot reach the nextInt() call at line 12 again unless that code is explicitly inside the loop's scope.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop Automatically Re-Reads Input / Variable Updates Without Assignment
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once they read the first guess into g, the while-loop will somehow obtain new guesses on each iteration (or that g will change automatically as the user types more input), so the loop corresponds to “keep guessing until correct.”
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, variables do not change unless the program assigns to them. The code reads input exactly once at line 13. After that, the while-loop (line 21) never calls x.nextInt() again and never prints a new prompt, so g stays the same forever. If the first guess is wrong and nonzero, execution repeatedly compares the same g against n and prints the same “Too high!/Too low!” message indefinitely, incrementing c each iteration. The mathematically expected behavior (one loop iteration per user guess) diverges because the program never performs another input operation inside the loop.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite loop with repeated "Too high!" or "Too low!" output; user is never prompted again and cannot enter another guess; guess counter increases extremely fast.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Misunderstanding hasNextInt(): Treating It Like a Read/Retry Mechanism
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that hasNextInt() will either (a) wait until the user enters an integer, or (b) automatically handle invalid input by preventing the program from continuing incorrectly.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Scanner.hasNextInt() only checks whether the next token is an integer; it does not consume input and does not prompt again. In this code, if the user types a non-integer first (or provides no integer), line 12 fails, line 13 never runs, and g remains 0. Then the while-loop starts with d=false and immediately takes the g==0 path (lines 39–41), setting d=true and exiting silently without telling the user what happened. This diverges from the expected behavior of repeatedly asking for guesses until correct.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: If first input is non-integer (or no integer is available), the program prints the prompt once and then terminates without any “Too high/low” feedback or re-prompting.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Guess Counter Increments Per Loop Iteration Rather Than Per User Guess
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that each time the program prints “Too high/Too low/Correct,” that corresponds to exactly one user guess, so incrementing c inside those branches correctly counts guesses.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Because the program does not read new guesses in the loop, the loop iterations do not correspond to new user guesses. Therefore c (incremented at lines 25/30/34) counts loop iterations, not guesses. If the first guess is wrong, c starts incrementing endlessly for the same single guess, so the final guess count (if it ever reached correct, which it cannot without new input) would be far larger than the number of guesses actually entered.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Incorrect (and potentially unbounded) guess count; with wrong first guess the count grows rapidly while repeating the same feedback.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that getting user input once before the loop is sufficient to handle multiple guesses. They think the while loop can repeatedly process the same input value and eventually work through the guessing game, without needing to ask for a new guess each iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student doesn't understand that in Java, variables retain their value unless explicitly reassigned. When the loop iterates, `g` remains 75 (from the first input), and there is no input statement inside the loop body to get a new value. The loop will infinitely compare the same initial guess against the secret number, never advancing to accept a new guess from the user.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite loop: After the first wrong guess is entered, the program will repeatedly print 'Too high!' or 'Too low!' (depending on that single input) without ever prompting for another guess or allowing the user to try again. The program never terminates.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Loop Continuation Logic Without State Update
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the while loop will naturally progress because it checks conditions and prints feedback. They may think that the program flow itself (printing feedback and incrementing the counter) constitutes progress toward completing the game.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student doesn't recognize that without updating `g` inside the loop, the condition `if(g!=0)` will always be true (since g is permanently 75), and the same comparison `if(h>n)` will always yield the same result. There is no mechanism to break out of the loop except by guessing correctly on the very first try, or by d remaining false forever (infinite loop).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Infinite repetition of the same output; the program never exits the while loop unless the first guess happens to be correct.

evidence.code_snippet: while(!d) block has no input statement

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that prompting the user once is enough, and that the loop will implicitly know to ask for the next input when it needs one.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, prompts and input statements are explicit operations. If you want to ask the user for input multiple times, you must include the `System.out.print("Guess...")` and `x.nextInt()` statements inside the loop body. The student has not included the prompt or input reading inside the while loop, so after the first guess, the user never sees another prompt and has no way to enter a new guess.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: User receives only one prompt at the start; no subsequent prompts are displayed, leaving the user confused and unable to provide additional guesses.

evidence.code_snippet: while(!d){ ... } (no prompt or input statement inside this block)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that once a variable (g) is assigned a value from an input source (x.nextInt()), placing that variable inside a loop will automatically cause the program to re-prompt the user or refresh the variable's value with new input on every iteration.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's execution model, variables only update when an assignment statement is explicitly executed. A Scanner method like nextInt() must be called inside the loop body to retrieve new data from the user during each iteration; otherwise, the variable retains its initial value forever, leading to an infinite loop.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that checking 'if(g!=0)' inside the loop acts as a mechanism to determine if more guesses are coming, without providing a way for 'g' to actually become 0 or change value inside the loop logic.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: A loop condition or an internal 'if' check cannot drive logic if the variables involved are static. The student lacks the understanding that a loop requires a state-change (like a new input) to make the conditional checks (h > n, h < n) meaningful across multiple iterations.
